subject: Tracy Smith: Catching Up With Old Friends
body:

April 27, 2007
Hi, 
      everybody,

  I'm always happy to fill in for 
      Russ at the news desk, but today I was thrilled to do it, because I got to 
      see a couple of buddies from the early days of "The Early Show." 
  Jon Frankel, who was a 
      correspondent on our show, now can claim the coolest of 
      titles: "documentary 
      filmmaker."  He made a film called "Hellfighters: a Season in 
      Harlem," which 
      will have its premiere at the 
      Tribeca Film Festival.  The film 
      is about the promise and struggles of a group of 
      teenagers, brought together to play football in Harlem.  Jon's got a great eye and big heart, 
      so I'm sure the movie is a 
      treat to watch; I can't wait to see 
      it.
  Mark McEwen was the weatherman when 
      I joined the show seven years 
      ago, and he became a pal I 
      could always count on to make me laugh, and, in turn, someone who'd laugh at my stupid 
      jokes.  
  He moved to Orlando a while 
      back, and in 2005, Mark suffered a terrible stroke. He was at the 
      airport at the time and didn't 
      recognize the symptoms so he kept 
      right on traveling. The stroke ended up almost killing 
      him. Luckily for all of us who 
      love him, he survived, and is 
      determined to make a full recovery. This morning he 
      came on the show to talk about recognizing the signs of a 
      stroke. I cannot emphasize enough how important it is to know these 
      signs because every moment is 
      critical.
  I know this because it happened to 
      my mom as well -- not once, but 
      twice. The first stroke, which happened when I was a 
      baby, nearly killed her. The second, which struck when I 
      was in high school, was just as severe, but thank goodness she 
      knew the symptoms and was able to get to the hospital in time to save her 
      life. With time, therapy, prayer and a lot of hard work, she's now 
      fully recovered. I'm so proud of her, but it's an experience I wish 
      no other family ever had to go through. So I'm grateful to 
      Mark, for his openness and courage in talking about this. I'm 
      also thankful because I had a few moments to hang out with him 
      this morning. The last time we spoke, he had a tough time talking and 
      I was a weepy mess. Today we were back to old form: telling stupid 
      jokes and laughing.  
      
  Tomorrow on the Saturday Early 
      Show, we'll have some important advice you'll want to remember the next 
      time you use your debit card. We'll also 
      preview some romantic summer movies, cook up a Mediterranean meal with 
      our "Chef on a 
      Shoestring," and enjoy a live 
      performance from rock/pop balladeer Jon McLaughlin in our Second Cup Cafe. 
      Hope you'll join us. 


Tracy 
       SmithEarlyShow@cbs.com
